header.activity: Family discussing a niche hobby and it's benefits
header.conv_type: Discussing, explaining, inquiring, advising, anecdote telling

body.u: so this winter camping thing is a bit unorthodox isn't it? I mean it d it is is
I mean you're not you're not the only people doing it
well as far as I can see we are
there's u nobody else up there
and the last time was up in Comrie was it?
yeah yeah twice we've gone out form Comrie erm
but I mean are these spots where people would camp in the summer?
no they're no they're not si you know
they're just out in the hill land
no it's wild camping but are th are they?
are they places you would choose to camp in? in if you went there in the summer as well?
erm I dunno I suppose suppose we might
the way we hit on them was that you've been going there since you were a kid
and you'd known these spots like going for a walk with your dad
and you knew that they would be relatively peaceful places
picturesque and so that's how we just ended up setting off
to try and find those places as targets
and we tend to wait until it's really cold and dry so actually
so there'll be absolutely nobody there?

well well it's more that erm you can go out as long you because then you keep dry if it's really i that's why we wait for the weather to drop temperature wise in many ways because once the ground's frozen underfoot we can go anywhere really whereas you know there's areas where that would've been very boggy if we if it hadn't been frozen
but it was very comfortable to walk on
very easy and you never your boots don't get wet and it's erm it's it so that's partly why in the winter we wait for it to be cold
yeah you know there's a book in this?
wild winter camping in Scotland I mean that's
well I'm sure people have done it
yeah and you could be taking erm you know these crazy Americans on tourtours and things like that
actually we'll show you some pictures
we'll show you some pictures later after we've done this erm of some winter cos we were away this weekend but that wasn't camping

but that's the ironic thing that we have just been to the Highlands which is a centre of er er kind of mountains around er Glen Coe and it was crowded but when we went to Comrie which is a village we left er Comrie High Street with people walking their dogs within half an hour we were in an area where we didn't see anybody for the next sixteen hours
so you know it was very peaceful

and then you've got you know there's places you try and go places where there's not too much light pollution so you can get the stars there was one camping trip we did at Corrour erm where we went up with for the Gemini meteor shower didn't we?
in December and erm we er there was very little light pollution so we just erm lay down in the tent with our heads outside on our boots and stared upwards and watched the meteor shower
with a hip flask in my hand
because there aren't many places here now where you can see the Milky Way
you'd have to go very far north I'd imagine to get away
we would see them at erm Abernethy wouldn't we? right
like in the middle of the wood
and I'm sure you know when we were growing up the sky looked different and the you know even in the suburban area I grew up you wouldn't have to go that far to see a dark sky
now it's so rare when you see the Milky Way it takes you by surprise
but a er any any spot of darkness in a city is quite weird I I've been driving erm cos this new job's in
er just off of er street
so erm when I drive back I drive round by the Parliament and then arthur's Seat and it's it's it's really odd cos that that bit is just pitch black
when you're driving up there in the dark and you forget you're in the middle of a city
but of course that doesn't help the the light pollution cos
the place we'd like to go to is er Kielder Forest in Northumberland
yeah I've been t through there
yeah yeah they erm there was something on the radio about that place a few a few m weeks or months ago where they they were having a performance of recorded birdsong

but the the they'd they'd hooked up all these speakers and it was to do with what bird the the raven and they they'd recorded ravens and they they'd hook up all these speakers in the trees and they were inviting people to come and like know lie in the in the forest and they they said absolute the the w because of the speakers the way they were set up they would feel like a flock of ravens would fly in
settle s make whatever noise ravens make
and then fly off again er I never found out h what the results were like but said it was gonna be really spectacular with all these sound engineers and things like that
and setting it up and RSPB erm sort of stuff but er
I can imagine cos one of the most spectacular things I've seen in recent weeks in where I work at there is a big tree outside and I left work one time at dusk and there were n tree was full of ravens
landing or taking off or circling in dusk with you know a beautiful pink glow to the sky behind and I hadn't really gone anywhere I'd just left work and you expect to have to travel
into the wild to see things like that
what what do ravens look like exactly cos they're just they're very similar to crows and whatnot aren't they?
yeah to be honest I wouldn't've known the difference but a friend of mine who knows about birds
said that they were ravens and that that they were ravens and that ravens stick together and crows are more solitary so
flock a flock of ravens yeah
well that'll be nice to see and and to hear the the is it er?
I would imagine with the distinctive call they have er and and and on your winter camping adventures have you ever sorta come across any weird wildlife?
don't know about weird but er you know obviously we see a lot of deer in Scotland erm
yeah I was just wondering what I saw this weekend although you weren't camping but whether it was a raven or what what birds would be up quite high at three thousand feet? would it be a raven?
no it was either it was one of those those

u.unclear: was it or was it black? no?

body.u: I think I think said it was a raven it was up quite high
need to look up the difference between ravens rooks and

body.u: we didn't see much did we? we didn't see
we we saw quite a lot of deer
on the cos I was on a different walk
oh yeah but camping we didn't see any deer but there was this time we were camping er w it wasn't strictly winter but we were camping erm
it was summer so it wasn't strictly winter
can I talk about camping? in the summer?

and erm we found this nice bit to camp that was on the little a little bit of a knoll and it looked really n really nice and it was a little bit flat and and everything so anyway we put got a tent up and then we were starting to cook a dinner and everything it was still light and I looklooked out of the tent and there were a whole load of deer watching us and we were obviously on their favourite bit

and so we stayed there cos we you know had everything set up and then we carried on it was starting to get dark and we were cooking and I just sort of glanced out and and they were still there lil and a b little baby had sat down on the grass but the others were all of like watching us

and literally we could s took photos as time went by it got darker and darker and all you saw was it the silhouettes of these ears and these heads and they just stayed looking at us d till it got dark didn't they?
they were really fed up I think that we were on their bit
it was the nearest pose a dear could take to standing with its hands on its hip
gently sort of shaking its head from side to side
I know it was very funny the photos were good I think we've got them somewhere the photos erm but w
there's something about camping outdoors where especiespecially in winter where you wake up and look out first thing in the morning
and the outdoors is right there there's not a layer of glass between you and it so
it's better even than staying in a hotel and so long as you're warm it's it's
we always eat the same thing when we're camping don't we?
in er we haven't quite moved to your idea of couscous
you haven't moved to couscous no
but we do do pasta and tuna and chilli and onion don't we and?

but we got really annoyed this time at Christmas because erm we bought these tins of of tuna that said it ha was in oil but they they were really dr they d had hardly any oil cos normally we use the oil in the tuna to cook the onion
and chilli and there w we couldn't get any ou squeeze any oil out of it d'you remember?
no and when you read the tin it said s erm
low amount of oil for health reasons or something like that
we wanted like like lots of oil
that keeps us going all night and read thing about and he was looking at four season bags and you were on the Web weren't you? and it was
telling you about how to use a four season bag
cos I was a bit chilly
I have to admit with my er sleeping bags that I've had since I was in the Scouts
so I wanted to invested one like 's which proper down bag
what was it it you you read the instructions?
well what they said was about down bags is that people buy them

without knowing a lot about them and the bags the manufacturers will say good down to minus two degrees or minus eight degrees but it said that's erm a f a fallacy really that people who know what they're doing know that your body sh body weight size er will make a difference your metabolism
will make a difference erm but significantly what you eat before you get in the sleeping bag will make a difference
so you should eat fatty food
and that will that will act as a fuel but the one thing also it said was you should get into the bag a down bag already warm so do star jumps
do star jumps then get in your bag
right don't include this bit in the book cos you're just gonna confuse them
so a bunch of bunch of deer staring you down as you're doing star jumps
no wonder the deer are staring
but no that makes sense though
it's not gonna heat you up
it's not gonna heat you up it's gonna keep your keep your heat but
well I'm sure they'll design one with an electric blanket get one one day
yeah heated heated down what do you call it under sheet
just you know with those erm like fibre optic or something inside inside that
you you know you press press them
yeah it'd have to have like a really good battery life or something just keep you toasty through the night that'd be nice
but we would never get cold in the tent well we do cooking but I mean you s you cook in your sleeping ba I mean not in your sleeping bag
you cook from your sleeping bag
leaning out into the porch yeah
and what sort of distance do you cover? before camping down I mean?
well these trips we didn't leave till two in the afternoon it got ho cold at half
er dark at half four so we did about twelve fifteen miles the second time didn't we?
oh well we did two days but we didn't go that far either
yeah because the second day we ran out of food so we er
you you di you you didn't forage?
we were only planning to go one night it was so gr it was so good we thought right we'll drop and down into and pick up some supplies
and er there was ha it was the day after Boxing Day there's almost nothing open was there?
there's one terri never go to the gr little shop in it's got absolutely nothing in it
I think we got an onion didn't we?
that's what I liked about when I was doing the walking in in in France in the Pyrenees
was stopping off in little villages and picking up the local sausage or the local cheese and the local pastries
cos even going from village to village in the mountains there's quite a stark difference between each
and it's we've kinda lost that a little bit here I think you know
eaeach village is gonna be very generic
in terms of the tea room and the the erm
the availability of the same instant noodles in each grocery shop
that's the lovely thing about France though is that er food is still central to their way of life and er
yeah I think it is in a lot of countries it just seems to be here where we've kinda
I think it's still central but it's sort of in a I mean depends what you mean by central really I mean
well the quality the quality of the food and erm
well it's not revered in any way it's it's it's just you know it's just stuck in
fuel with lots of calories and

well we were we were talking about this at the party last night about how you know people say some people turn their nose up at the farmers' market cos it's it is more expensive and it is by the way but it is of of course it's gonna be

and you know you can be it's easy to be cynical about these things but really it's it's very important I mean when you go to the market in a Spanish town or in a French village it you that is the farmers' market the difference is
here we've got to label it and brand it because people
otherwise want their twenty P cucumber and
there's they don't realise that that's it's it's it's not really sustainable
also people forget that we grew up erm really with a system where you would go out to the shops every day and you would erm bring fresh
vegetables er back and the the
that's the one thing that people take have lost
and the cost would be a a much higher proportion of your weekly income than it is now

so people use supermarkets because they're you know making all this produce or selling all this produce cheaply but for one thing they've shipped halfway the round the country cos they're doing everything in bulk and through distribution centres and erm
well also they're doing those deals with the farmers where the farmers are
almost almost yeah well I mean it's a double edged sword isn't it really?
farmers are it's not c it can't be a disaster for anybody otherwise erm nobody would do it you know there'd be no money in it at all so it can't be that bad but
that's why I'm always prepared to spend our money on good food
I think if somebody's taken the trouble to produce something well then

the the the person I met so anyway a faux pas

if if for some reason you can't get through it's a it's a disaster and
oh god you know used to have to panic whereas maybe twenty years ago we wouldn't've reacted in the same way
I dunno I dunno think that some people have always been like that but cos mobiles are so ubiquitous you

yeah there's no need really is there?
you've got it on you so if there's an emergency you b you'll have to take it out are you gonna get a signal?
well you see I'm even a little bit extreme on that front because er I think people shouldn't carry a phone thinking that they can call for help
so I think the phones should be taken off them as soon as they go into the hills and then
they know they have to rely on themselves you know have to be self reliant have to plan properly

chasing you and not checking if you've got the right kkit but actually taking bits of kit off you
